Uptick in Inflation Could Pressure Fed

summary-body.p: A burst of higher inflation is fueling debate about whether the Federal Reserve should move sooner to reduce its support for the U.S. economy than currently anticipated.

headline.main-hed: Uptick in Inflation Could Pressure Fed
headline.deck: Consumer Prices Post Fastest Increase Since February 2013

article-body.p: A burst of higher inflation is fueling debate about whether the Federal Reserve should move sooner to reduce its support for the U.S. economy than currently anticipated.

Consumer prices rose 0.4% in May from a month earlier, the most in more than a year, the Labor Department said. That reflected higher household costs for everything from groceries and gasoline to rent and medical care. Core prices, which strip out volatile food and energy costs, climbed 0.3%, the most since August 2011.
Tuesday's report showed the overall consumer-price index up 2.1% from a year earlier.

link.highlight: IMF Cuts U.S. 2014 Growth Forecast to 2%
U.S. Housing Starts Fall 6.5% in May
U.S. Producer Prices Fall 0.2% in May

list-item.link: Capital Journal Daybreak: Receive the Journal's morning rundown in your inbox

article-body.p: The Fed targets annual inflation of 2%, a pace it views as healthy for price stability and economic growth. But the central bank prefers a separate measure—the Commerce Department's price index for personal consumption expenditures—that has shown less-dramatic price increases and inflation still running below its target, at 1.6% in April.
Still, both measures suggest inflation picked up in the spring after two years of sluggishness.

The stronger inflation reading, along with continued improvement in the labor market, could suggest the U.S. economy is performing better than Fed policy makers realize, economists said. The brightening picture is also likely to complicate debate within the Fed about when to raise short-term interest rates. The Fed has kept rates near zero since late 2008 and purchased trillions of dollars in bonds to lower borrowing costs and spur spending, investment and hiring. While the Fed has begun reducing the pace of its bond purchases, it has indicated it wouldn't raise rates until sometime in 2015.

"We have an unemployment rate that's been falling faster than the Fed expected and now we've got an inflation rate that's been rising more than the Fed expected," said John Ryding, chief economist at RDQ Economics LLC. "It raises some interesting questions for those at the Fed who've argued that there's so much slack in the labor market. It really brings into question how much slack there is," along with how much more support the economy needs from the Fed.

The Fed, which concludes a two-day policy meeting Wednesday, is expected to reduce its monthly bond purchases by another $10 billion to $35 billion a month, staying on track to wind down that program later this year.

Fed officials have been looking for higher inflation for reassurance the economy is stable as their bond-buying program ends. But if inflation continues to accelerate faster than the steady pace they have projected, officials could give stronger consideration to raising short-term interest rates sooner.
Fed officials are also set Wednesday to release updated forecasts for economic growth and inflation, which they use to steer their decision making.

The central bank's preferred inflation gauge has run below target for two years, though it has picked up recently. In April, the PCE price index was up 1.6% from a year earlier, with core prices up 1.4%.
In March, Fed officials projected inflation wouldn't hit its 2% target until next year.

The CPI has run at 2% or above for two straight months. The CPI and PCE price index typically run in tandem over time but often diverge month to month because they are calculated differently. Over the past 25 years, PCE inflation has been about 0.5 percentage point lower per year than the CPI.

Tuesday's report on the Labor Department's consumer-price index showed prices rose across an array of items. Energy prices climbed 0.9%, though the Labor Department said that rise partly reflected semiannual adjustments to electricity bills in California. Food prices rose 0.5%. Shelter prices, reflecting home rent, increased 0.3%.

In a sign the labor market remains below full strength, Americans' inflation-adjusted average weekly earnings fell 0.1% in May from April. That reflected higher price increases that outpaced an increase in workers' pay. The average workweek held steady.
Write to Josh Mitchell at joshua.mitchell@wsj.com
